sites.name: Basilica di San Nicola
sites.description: Bari's magnificent 11th-century Romanesque basilica dedicated to Saint Nicholas, the patron saint of sailors and children. The basilica houses the relics of Saint Nicholas and features stunning Byzantine-influenced architecture with beautiful mosaics, a golden ceiling, and an impressive crypt.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful year-round, but early morning offers the best light for photography and fewer crowds. Summer brings more visitors but also longer opening hours.
sites.booking_tips: Free entry to the main church. Small fee for the crypt. Modest dress required. Check mass times if you want to experience a service.

sites.name: Bari Vecchia (Old Town)
sites.description: Bari's enchanting medieval old town, a maze of narrow cobblestone streets, whitewashed houses, and historic churches. This atmospheric neighborhood showcases traditional Puglian architecture, local craftsmen making orecchiette pasta in the streets, and authentic local life away from tourist crowds.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most atmospheric in spring and autumn when temperatures are pleasant. Summer can be hot but offers vibrant street life. Winter brings fewer tourists and authentic local atmosphere.
sites.booking_tips: Free to explore. Wear comfortable walking shoes for the cobblestone streets. Best explored on foot with no specific route - just wander and discover hidden corners.

sites.name: Castello Normanno-Svevo
sites.description: A massive 12th-century Norman-Swabian castle built by Frederick II, featuring impressive defensive walls, towers, and a moat. The castle now houses the Bari Provincial Art Gallery and offers panoramic views of the old town and Adriatic Sea.
sites.seasonal_notes: Perfect for hot summer afternoons. Spring and autumn offer comfortable temperatures for exploring the castle grounds. Winter visits are peaceful with fewer tourists.
sites.booking_tips: Entrance fee required. Guided tours available. Photography allowed. The castle provides excellent views of the old town and harbor.

sites.name: Lungomare Nazario Sauro
sites.description: Bari's beautiful waterfront promenade along the Adriatic Sea, offering stunning sea views, palm trees, and a perfect place for evening strolls. The promenade is lined with cafes, restaurants, and provides access to the city's beaches and harbor.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most beautiful at sunset and in the evening. Summer offers a lively atmosphere with street performers and outdoor dining. Spring and autumn provide pleasant temperatures for walking.
sites.booking_tips: Free to walk along. Many restaurants offer outdoor seating with sea views. Perfect for photography, especially at sunset. Can be busy during peak dining hours.

sites.name: Cattedrale di San Sabino
sites.description: Bari's impressive 12th-century cathedral dedicated to Saint Sabinus, featuring beautiful Romanesque architecture, a rose window, and an elegant bell tower. The cathedral showcases the city's religious heritage and offers a peaceful retreat from the bustling old town.
sites.seasonal_notes: Peaceful atmosphere year-round. Early morning offers the most spiritual experience. Summer brings more visitors but maintains its architectural beauty.
sites.booking_tips: Free entry. Modest dress required. Photography may be restricted during services. Located in the heart of the old town.

sites.name: Piazza Mercantile
sites.description: A beautiful historic square in the old town featuring the Colonna della Giustizia (Justice Column) and surrounded by historic buildings. This atmospheric square was once the commercial heart of medieval Bari and now serves as a gathering place for locals and visitors.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most atmospheric in the evening when locals gather. Summer brings street performers and increased activity. Winter offers peaceful charm with authentic local atmosphere.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Perfect for photography and people-watching. Many restaurants and cafes surround the square. Arrive early for dinner reservations.

sites.name: Museo Archeologico di Santa Scolastica
sites.description: A fascinating museum housed in a former Benedictine monastery, showcasing archaeological finds from ancient Bari and the surrounding Puglia region. The museum features Roman, Greek, and medieval artifacts that tell the story of Bari's rich history.
sites.seasonal_notes: Perfect for hot summer afternoons or rainy days. The museum provides insight into Bari's ancient past and cultural heritage.
sites.booking_tips: Small entrance fee. Guided tours available. Located in the old town near other attractions. Check for special exhibitions and events.

sites.name: Teatro Petruzzelli
sites.description: Bari's magnificent 19th-century opera house, one of the largest theaters in Italy, featuring beautiful neoclassical architecture and excellent acoustics. The theater hosts opera, ballet, and classical music performances throughout the year.
sites.seasonal_notes: Year-round performances with seasonal programming. Summer may have outdoor events. Winter offers traditional opera season. Check schedule for current performances.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets required for performances. Book in advance for popular shows. Guided tours available when no performances scheduled. Photography may be restricted.

sites.name: Piazza del Ferrarese
sites.description: A charming square in the old town featuring traditional Puglian architecture and local craftsmen making orecchiette pasta in the streets. This authentic square offers a glimpse into traditional Bari life and local culinary traditions.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most authentic in the morning when locals are making pasta. Summer brings more tourists but maintains local character. Winter offers the most authentic experience.
sites.booking_tips: Free to visit. Watch pasta-making demonstrations. Many local restaurants serve traditional orecchiette. Perfect for photography of local life.

sites.name: Porto Vecchio (Old Port)
sites.description: Bari's historic fishing port where traditional fishing boats still operate alongside modern vessels. The port offers authentic maritime atmosphere, fresh seafood restaurants, and beautiful views of the Adriatic Sea and old town skyline.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most atmospheric in the early morning when fishing boats return. Summer brings more activity and tourists. Spring and autumn offer pleasant temperatures for exploring.
sites.booking_tips: Free to walk around. Many restaurants serve fresh local seafood. Photography allowed. Can be busy during peak dining hours.

sites.name: Chiesa di San Gregorio
sites.description: A beautiful 11th-century church featuring Romanesque architecture and Byzantine influences, located in the heart of the old town. This smaller church offers a more intimate religious experience and showcases Bari's early Christian heritage.
sites.seasonal_notes: Peaceful atmosphere year-round. Early morning offers the most spiritual experience. Summer brings some visitors but maintains its intimate feel.
sites.booking_tips: Free entry. Modest dress required. Photography may be restricted during services. Located in the historic center near other attractions.

sites.name: Via Sparano da Bari
sites.description: Bari's main shopping street featuring modern boutiques, local crafts, and traditional Puglian products. This pedestrian-friendly street offers a mix of contemporary shopping and local specialties including ceramics, olive oil, and regional wines.
sites.seasonal_notes: Active year-round with shops open most days. Summer brings more tourists and street vendors. Winter offers more authentic local shopping experience.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Many shops offer local Puglian specialties. Bargaining not expected but some shops may offer discounts. Perfect for souvenir shopping.

sites.name: Torre di San Antonio Abate
sites.description: A medieval tower that was part of Bari's defensive walls, offering views of the old town and harbor. This historic structure provides insight into Bari's strategic importance as a port city and offers a different perspective of the city.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most beautiful at sunset for photography. Spring and autumn offer comfortable temperatures. Summer can be hot but offers the clearest views of the harbor.
sites.booking_tips: Free access. Requires moderate fitness for climbing. Wear comfortable shoes. Best reached by foot from the old town center.

sites.name: Piazza Massari
sites.description: A smaller, more intimate square featuring historic buildings and local cafes. This quiet square offers a peaceful retreat from the main tourist areas and provides a glimpse into everyday life in Bari's old town.
sites.seasonal_notes: Peaceful year-round with fewer tourists. Early morning offers the most authentic atmosphere. Summer brings some visitors but maintains its charm.
sites.booking_tips: Free to visit. Perfect for quiet contemplation and photography. Located away from main tourist routes. Many local cafes offer traditional Puglian coffee.

sites.name: Chiesa di San Marco dei Veneziani
sites.description: A small but historically significant church dating from the 11th century, featuring beautiful Romanesque architecture and Venetian influences. This church represents Bari's connections with Venice and showcases the city's maritime trading heritage.
sites.seasonal_notes: Peaceful atmosphere year-round. Early morning offers the most spiritual experience. Summer brings some visitors but maintains its intimate feel.
sites.booking_tips: Free entry. Modest dress required. Photography may be restricted. Located in the historic center near other attractions.

sites.name: Fontana di Piazza Umberto
sites.description: A beautiful 19th-century fountain located in one of Bari's main squares, featuring traditional Italian design elements and serving as a gathering point for locals. The fountain represents the city's artistic heritage and provides a refreshing spot in the Mediterranean climate.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful year-round. Afternoon offers good lighting for photography. Summer brings more activity around the fountain area.
sites.booking_tips: Free to visit. Perfect for photography and people-watching. Located in the heart of the city center. Can be crowded during peak tourist season.

sites.name: Punta San Cataldo
sites.description: A beautiful natural promontory on the outskirts of Bari, offering spectacular views of the Adriatic Sea and the city skyline. This protected area provides excellent walking opportunities and some of the most dramatic coastal scenery near Bari.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most beautiful at sunset for photography. Spring and autumn offer comfortable temperatures for walking. Summer can be hot but offers the clearest views.
sites.booking_tips: Free access. Requires moderate fitness for walking. Wear appropriate footwear. Best reached by car or public transport. Perfect for nature photography.
